section.title: Solor definitional knowledge
section.para: In order to represent the various domains of healthcare, Solor "stands on the shoulder of giants" by building on existing content from SNOMED CT®, LOINC®, and RxNorm. The purpose of this section is to discuss the categories within Solor where concepts reside, as well as the relationships used to define the concepts. Ultimately, the goal of this representation of concepts and their relationships would support the description logic component of Solor.

section.title: Top level categories
section.para: In SNOMED, various hierarchies (e.g. Procedures, Clinical Findings, etc) are used to store and maintain various concepts. These hierarchies are typically modeled such that higher level concepts (i.e. Disorder of endocrine system) are more generic than lower level concepts, which are more granular (e.g. Type 1 diabetes mellitus). Through a series of Is a relationships, which will be explained in the next section, one could traverse down the hierarchy from a top level generic concept to a very specific concept. In an attempt to gather 'like' concepts, Solor created top level categories of concepts to 'house' concepts that belong to those categories. This section will describe the intent and purpose of these categories.

section.title: Body structure
section.para: Contains both normal and abnormal anatomical structures.
Example of Body structures include Structure of left lower limb (body structure), Anastamosis, Roux-en-y (morphologic abnormality) and Skin xenograft (body structure).

section.title: Environment or geographical location
section.para: This hierarchy contains the types of environments and named locations such as countries.

section.title: Event
section.para: Events are different from procedures in that they are occurrences that impact health or health care.

section.title: Medication
section.para: This hierarchy is comparable to the Pharmaceutical / biologic product in SNOMED CT® and used to represent drug products.

section.title: Object
section.para: Natural and man-made objects encountered in the healthcare environment.

section.title: Organism
section.para: An individual entity that exhibits the properties of life.

section.title: Phenomenon
section.para: This Hierarchy contains Observable Entities, Clinical Findings, and Disorders.

section.title: Procedure
section.para: Procedures are actions performed in the provision of health care.

section.title: Qualifier value
section.para: Miscellaneous concepts used to represent the values for definitional relationships in SNOMED CT®.

section.title: Record artifact
section.para: The Record artifact hierarchy is used to represent the names of a clinical document or parts of a clinical document.

section.title: Situation with explicit context
section.para: Clinical findings or Procedures that have contextual information applied to them. This can include concepts like Family history and Procedures performed in the past or planned in the future.

section.title: SNOMED CT® Model Component
section.para: Concepts and attributes used to create and organize SNOMED CT®.

section.title: Social context
section.para: Social conditions and circumstances, for example ethnic groups, life styles, occupations, and religions.

section.title: Special concept
section.para: Inactive and navigational concepts from SNOMED CT®.

section.title: Specimen
section.para: Material collected for examination or analysis. Usually from a patient but can also be obtained from other sources, for example a catheter or the environment.

section.title: Stages and scales
section.para: SNOMED CT® concepts used to represent stages, grades and scales.

section.title: Substance
section.para: Physical matter from which something is made or which has discrete existence. This hierarchy includes allergens, agents, substances, and materials used to define Medications, Phenomenon, and Procedures.

section.title: Relationship types
section.para: As alluded in earlier sections, each concept with a name by itself does not provide any additional knowledge to reason. If the concept "Disorder of endocrine system" is placed into a bucket of like concepts, such as "Type 1 diabetes mellitus", without any formal definition, one could not possibly deduce that "Type 1 diabetes mellitus" is a type of endocrine system disorder. Therefore, a series of relationships must be used to properly define the concept so that the concept could contain additional knowledge for reasoning to occur. With the simple example of diabetes, it may seem that one could simply create an "Is A" relationship to relate "Disorder of endocrine system" and "Type 1 diabetes mellitus". Although it may connect these two concepts, there needs to be additional relationship types to further define each concept to provide more context and knowledge such that a concept is further defined and could provide additional knowledge. This section describes the relationship types of Solor and provides example of its usage.

formalpara.title: Definition
formalpara.para: Is a Relationships are used to represent a hierarchical parent/child relationship between two concepts. Is a relationships should only be used in the cases of a true parent child relationship between two concepts. Only proximal Is a relationships should be distributed in releases, however they may exist in modeling views. Concepts can have more than one Is a relationship but must have at least one Is a Relationship.

formalpara.title: Utility
formalpara.para: Is a Relationships give a hierarchical structure to Solor and provide a mechanism to query and retrieve subtype concepts.

formalpara.title: Example
formalpara.para: Bacterial pneumonia (disorder) has two Is a Relationships, one to Bacterial lower respiratory infection (disorder) and another to Infective pneumonia (disorder).

table.title: Phenomenon Relationship Types Sub-Domain and Range

row.entry: Subject of record or other provider of history (person) OR
Person with characteristic related to subject of record (person)
Anatomical or acquired body structure (body structure)
Ordinal or quantitative value (qualifier value) OR

formalpara.title: Definition
formalpara.para: Associated morphology is used to define Phenomenon by specifying the morphologic changes that are characteristic of a disease.

formalpara.title: Utility
formalpara.para: The Associated morphology is useful in identifying the morphologic change associated with a disease. This is usually grouped with a finding site to fully define a disease.

formalpara.title: Example
formalpara.para:
[ Elbow fracture]
has an Associated morphology of Fracture (morphologic abnormality)

formalpara.title: Definition
formalpara.para: The Associated with attribute is used to define Phenomenon to specify an association between two concepts that doesn't explicitly state a causal relationship.

formalpara.title: Utility
formalpara.para: The Associated with attribute is useful to define higher level concepts that collect the various subtype attributes.

formalpara.title: Example
formalpara.para:
[ Anemia associated with AIDS]
has an Associated with of Acquired immune deficiency syndrome (disorder)

section.title: Associated With Subtype Roles
section.para: Associated With has three Subtype Attributes: Causative agent, Due to, and Temporally related to.

section.title: Causative agent

formalpara.title: Definition
formalpara.para: The term disease causative agent usually refers to the biological pathogen that causes a disease, such as a virus, parasite, fungus, or bacterium, or can refer to a toxin or toxic chemical that causes illness.

formalpara.title: Utility
formalpara.para: The Causative agent attribute is useful to identify the cause of a disease that correctly place the concept in the proper hierarchy and aid in search and retrieval of concepts.

formalpara.title: Example
formalpara.para: Welding of stainless steel is a well recognised cause of occupational asthma, the chrome in the fume has been shown to be the cause in some challenge tests. Non-stainless steel welding is more problematic as specific causative agents have not been demonstrated, but nevertheless occupational asthma occurs. Probably the best evidence comes from longitudinal studies of apprentice welders. Priapism caused by drug (disorder) has a Causative agent of Drug or medicament (substance).

section.para: Welders asthma (disorder) has Causative agent of Welding fume (substance)

formalpara.title: Definition
formalpara.para: Due to is used to relate a Phenomenon directly with its causal Phenomenon, Event or Procedure. If the Phenomenon, Event, or Procedure does not directly cause the disease then the parent attribute of Associated with should be used instead.

formalpara.title: Utility
formalpara.para: Due to is used to define concepts where a Phenonmenon, Event or Procedure directly causes a Phenomenon.

formalpara.title: Example
formalpara.para:
[ Epilepsy due to cerebrovascular accident]
has a Due to relationship of Cerebrovascular accident (disorder)

formalpara.title: Definition
formalpara.para: Temporally related to is used in the Phenomenon hierarchy to specify the clinical entity occurring either before, during or after a Phenomenon or Procedure.

formalpara.title: Utility
formalpara.para: Temporally related to is a parent attribute that can be used to describe a more general concept that will collect the subtypes of Before or During AND/OR after.

formalpara.title: Example
formalpara.para: This attribute is currently not used to define a concept in Solor. However the subtype attributes are used.

section.title: Temporally related to Subtype Roles
section.para: Temporally related to has two subtype attributes, Before and During AND/OR after.

formalpara.title: Definition
formalpara.para: Before is used in the Phenomenon hierarchy to define complications that occur prior to a procedure.

formalpara.title: Utility
formalpara.para: To define Phenomenon that are complications that occur prior to a procedure the Before attribute is used to represent the procedure that the Phenomenon occurs prior to.

formalpara.title: Example
formalpara.para: This attribute has not been used to define a concept in Solor.

formalpara.title: Definition
formalpara.para: The After attribute is used to define Phenomenon that occur after another Phenomenon or Procedure.

formalpara.title: Utility
formalpara.para: After indicates a sequence of events and not necessarily a cause. If a cause is implied then a Due to relationship should be used instead.

formalpara.title: Example
formalpara.para:
[ Postablative testicular hypofunction]
has an After relationship of Testicular ablation (procedure)

formalpara.title: Definition
formalpara.para: The During attribute is used to define Phenomenon that occur during another Phenomenon or Procedure.

formalpara.title: Utility
formalpara.para: During indicates a sequence of events and not necessarily a cause. If a cause is implied then a Due to relationship should be used instead.

formalpara.title: Example
formalpara.para:
[ Bleeding during surgery requiring transfusion]
has a During relationship of Surgical procedure (procedure)

formalpara.title: Definition
formalpara.para: The Clinical course attribute is used in the Phenomenon hierarchy to represent both the course and onset of a disease.

formalpara.title: Utility
formalpara.para: Course and onset are two categorizations that are typically used in conjunction with each other though sometimes are considered separately. For example, sudden onset and short-term courses

formalpara.title: Example
formalpara.para:
[ Chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy]
has a Clinical course of Chronic (qualifier value)

formalpara.title: Definition
formalpara.para: The Characterizes attribute is used in the Phenomenon hierarchy to specify the process the property describes and depends.

formalpara.title: Utility
formalpara.para: Describe why the role is useful here.

formalpara.title: Example
formalpara.para:
[ Pulse rate]
has a Characterizes of Cardiac process (qualifier value)

formalpara.title: Definition
formalpara.para: The Component attribute is used in the Phenomenon hierarchy to specify the numerator of a relational property type.

formalpara.title: Utility
formalpara.para: Describe why the role is useful here.

formalpara.title: Example
formalpara.para: Hepatitis antibody radioimmunoassay (procedure) has a Component of Hepatitis antibody (substance)

formalpara.title: Definition
formalpara.para: The Direct site attribute is used in the Phenomenon hierarchy to define the direct and sometimes the indirect entity on which and observation is made. An indirect site is allowed to be specified when a direct observation cannot be made.

formalpara.title: Utility
formalpara.para: Describe why the role is useful here.

formalpara.title: Example
formalpara.para: Heart rate measured at systemic artery (observable entity) has a Direct site of Systemic arterial structure (body structure)

formalpara.title: Definition
formalpara.para: The Episodicity attribute is used in the Phenomenon hierarchy to define the episode of care provided by a healthcare provider.

formalpara.title: Utility
formalpara.para: Episodicity is not used define the episode of disease experienced by the patient. Episodicity is not currently used to define concepts in Solor, but can be used to define new concepts or post-coordinated expressions as needed.

formalpara.title: Example
formalpara.para: Arthritis (disorder) with Episodicity = First episode (qualifier value) represents the first time the patient presents to their healthcare provider with arthritis.

formalpara.title: Definition
formalpara.para: The Finding informer attribute is used to define the entity that informs about the clinical finding.

formalpara.title: Utility
formalpara.para: Finding informer is used to differentiate patient vs provider determined findings. Finding informer is frequently grouped with Finding method.

formalpara.title: Example
formalpara.para: Complaining of cough (finding) has a Finding informer of Subject of record or other provider of history (person)

formalpara.title: Definition
formalpara.para: The Finding method attribute is used in the Phenomenon hierarchy to define the way a finding was determined.

formalpara.title: Utility
formalpara.para: Finding method is usually used in conjunction with the Finding informer attribute.

formalpara.title: Example
formalpara.para: Finding of pulse taking by auscultation (finding) has a Finding method of Auscultation (procedure)

formalpara.title: Definition
formalpara.para: The Finding site attribute is used in the Phenomenon hierarchy to define the body site affected.

formalpara.title: Utility
formalpara.para: Describe why the role is useful here.

formalpara.title: Example
formalpara.para: Cervical lymph node abscess (disorder) has a Finding Site of Cervical lymph node structure (body structure)

formalpara.title: Definition
formalpara.para: Retired

formalpara.title: Definition
formalpara.para: The Has interpretation attribute is used in the Phenomenon hierarchy to define the judgement of the thing being evaluated or interpreted in the Interprets attribute.

formalpara.title: Utility
formalpara.para: Has interpretation is grouped together to with Interprets to represent what is being evaluated with its interpretation.

formalpara.title: Example
formalpara.para: Electrocardiogram normal (finding) has a Has interpretation of Normal (qualifier value)

formalpara.title: Definition
formalpara.para: The Interprets attribute is used in the Phenomenon hierarchy to define the entity being evaluated.

formalpara.title: Utility
formalpara.para: Interprets is grouped together to with Has Interpretation to represent what is being evaluated with its interpretation.

formalpara.title: Example
formalpara.para: Electrocardiogram normal (finding) has an Interprets of Electrocardiographic procedure (procedure)

formalpara.title: Definition
formalpara.para: Pathological processes is used in the Phenomenon hierarchy to define the underlying pathological process of a disorder that is not structural and cannot be represented using the Associated morphology relationship type.

formalpara.title: Utility
formalpara.para: Describe why the role is useful here.

formalpara.title: Example
formalpara.para: Lupus hepatitis (disorder) has a Pathological Process of Autoimmune process (qualifier value)

table.title: Procedure Relationship Types Sub-Domain and Range

row.entry: Anatomical or acquired body structure (body structure)
Anatomical or acquired body structure (body structure)
Anatomical or acquired body structure (body structure)
Donor for medical or surgical procedure (social concept) OR
Administration of substance via specific route
Ordinal or quantitative value (qualifier value) OR

formalpara.title: Definition
formalpara.para: This attribute describes the route used to access the site of a procedure and used to distinguish open, closed or percutaneous procedures.

formalpara.title: Utility
formalpara.para: Describe why the role is useful here.

formalpara.title: Example
formalpara.para: Open removal of foreign body from colon (procedure) has an Access of Open approach - access (qualifier value)

formalpara.title: Definition
formalpara.para: The Component attribute is used in the Procedure hierarchy to represent what is being observed or measured.

formalpara.title: Utility
formalpara.para: The Component attribute is used specifically to define Evaluation procedures.

formalpara.title: Example
formalpara.para: Fluorescent antibody measurement (procedure) has a Component of Antibody (substance)

formalpara.title: Definition
formalpara.para: The Direct substance attribute is used in the Procedure hierarchy to represent the Substance or Medicine on which the procedure's method directly acts.

formalpara.title: Utility
formalpara.para: Medications are currently not used to define Procedures, but can be used in Extensions and Post-coordinated expressions.

formalpara.title: Example
formalpara.para: Intra-amniotic prostaglandin instillation (procedure) has a Direct substance of Prostaglandin (substance)

formalpara.title: Definition
formalpara.para: Has focus is used in the Procedure hierarchy to define the focus of a procedure.

formalpara.title: Utility
formalpara.para: Describe why the role is useful here.

formalpara.title: Example
formalpara.para: Viral screening (procedure) has a Has focus of Viral disease (disorder)

formalpara.title: Definition
formalpara.para: The Has intent attribute is used in the Procedure hierarchy to define the intent of a procedure.

formalpara.title: Utility
formalpara.para: Describe why the role is useful here.

formalpara.title: Example
formalpara.para: Diagnostic procedure (procedure) has a Has intent of Diagnostic intent (qualifier value)

formalpara.title: Definition
formalpara.para: Has specimen is used in the Procedure hierarchy to define the type of specimen a measurement or observation is performed.

formalpara.title: Utility
formalpara.para: Describe why the role is useful here.

formalpara.title: Example
formalpara.para: Give an example of correct use here.

section.para: All or part of currently has one subtype role, Part of.

section.para: Part of has three subtype roles that can be further used to define Body structures.

section.title: Regional part of Subtype Roles
section.para: Regional part of has one subtype role that can be further used to define Body structures.

formalpara.title: Definition
formalpara.para: Laterality is an attribute used to represent the side of the body to which the body structure belongs. It is only used for body structures that are symmetric to both sides of the body and is not used to represent sidedness.

formalpara.title: Utility
formalpara.para: Laterality is useful for defining body structures that are symmetric to both sides of the body only. There are currently no attributes used to represent sidedness that could define concepts like Structure of left side of heart (body structure).

formalpara.title: Example
formalpara.para: Structure of right knee region (body structure) has a Laterality of Right (qualifier value)

section.title: Situation with explicit context relationship types

table.title: Situation with explicit context Relationship Types Sub-Domain and Range

formalpara.title: Definition
formalpara.para: Associated finding links the Situation with explicit context concept to the related Phenomenon or Event

formalpara.title: Utility
formalpara.para: The Associated finding attribute is used to link a Phenomenon or Event to the contextual information contained in the Finding context, Subject relationship context and Temporal context attributes.

formalpara.title: Example
formalpara.para: Family history: Diabetes mellitus (situation) has an Associated finding of Diabetes mellitus (disorder)

section.title: Associated procedure

formalpara.title: Definition
formalpara.para: Associated procedure links the Situation with explicit context concept to the related Procedure

section.para: The Associated procedure attribute is used to link a Procedure to the contextual information contained in the Procedure context, Subject relationship context and Temporal context attributes.

formalpara.title: Example
formalpara.para: 183985008 |Renal transplant planned (situation)| has an Associated procedure of Transplant of kidney (procedure)

formalpara.title: Definition
formalpara.para: Finding context is used in the Situation with explicit context hierarchy to represent whether a Phenomenon or Event is known or unknown.

formalpara.title: Utility
formalpara.para: Finding context is used to define the contextual information about whether a Phenomenon or Event is known or unknown.

formalpara.title: Example
formalpara.para: Chvostek sign positive (situation) has a Finding context of Known present (qualifier value)

formalpara.title: Definition
formalpara.para: Procedure context is used in the Situation with explicit context hierarchy to represent the status of a Procedure

formalpara.title: Utility
formalpara.para: Procedure context is used to define the contextual information about the status of a Procedure.

formalpara.title: Example
formalpara.para: Hemodialysis procedure done (situation) has a Procedure context of Done (qualifier value)

formalpara.title: Definition
formalpara.para: Subject relationship context is used in the Situation with explicit context hierarchy to represent the relationship of the finding or procedure to the subject of record. This can be the subject of record or someone else.

formalpara.title: Utility
formalpara.para: Subject relationship context is useful for representing the contextual information regarding who the Procedure, Phenomenon, or Event is about.

formalpara.title: Example
formalpara.para: History of arthritis (situation) has a Subject relationship context of Subject of record (person). Family history: Alzheimer's disease (situation) has a Subject relationship context of Person in family of subject (person)

formalpara.title: Definition
formalpara.para: This attribute represents the time of a procedure or finding when used in the Situation with explicit context hierarchy

formalpara.title: Utility
formalpara.para: Temporal context is useful for representing the contextual information regarding when a Procedure, Phenomenon, or Event occurred.

formalpara.title: Example
formalpara.para: Hip replacement planned (situation) has a Temporal context of Current or specified time (qualifier value). The concept History of malignant neoplasm (situation) has a Temporal context of In the past (qualifier value)

table.title: Medication Relationship Types Sub-Domain and Range

row.entry: Count of base and modification pair
Count of base of active ingredient

formalpara.title: Definition
formalpara.para: The Has ingredient attribute allows for the definition of a Substance that can be used as an ingredient for a Medicinal product.

formalpara.title: Utility
formalpara.para: This attribute is not used to define Medicinal product, but is used as a parent attribute for Has active ingredient. It is considered a grouper attribute for other ingredient attributes like Has active ingredient. It can also be used for querying other ingredient attributes to find any Medicinal product with a specific ingredient regardless of the subtype attribute used.

section.title: Has ingredient Subtype Roles
section.para: Has ingredient has one subtype role to further define Medications.

formalpara.title: Definition
formalpara.para: Has active ingredient represents the substance that has a therapeutic action

formalpara.title: Utility
formalpara.para: Describe why the role is useful here.

formalpara.title: Example
formalpara.para: Give an example of correct use here.

section.title: Has active ingredient Subtype Roles
section.para: Has active ingredient has one subtype role to further define Medications.

formalpara.title: Definition
formalpara.para: Has precise active ingredient represents the most specific substance present in the manufactured dose form

formalpara.title: Utility
formalpara.para: Describe why the role is useful here.

formalpara.title: Example
formalpara.para: Give an example of correct use here.

formalpara.title: Definition
formalpara.para: Has basis of strength substance is used to represent an active ingredient or part of the active ingredient that the strength of a product is based on.

formalpara.title: Utility
formalpara.para: Describe why the role is useful here.

formalpara.title: Example
formalpara.para: Give an example of correct use here.

table.title: Substance Relationship Types Sub-Domain and Range

formalpara.title: Definition
formalpara.para: The Has disposition attribute relates a Substance with the behavior that the substance will exhibit or participate in.

formalpara.title: Utility
formalpara.para: The Has disposition attribute allows for the definition of behaviors like Antimicrobial (disposition), Decarboxylase (disposition), and Chelating agent (disposition).

formalpara.title: Example
formalpara.para: Estradiol (substance) has a Has disposition of Estrogen (disposition)

formalpara.title: Definition
formalpara.para: The Is modification of attribute is used in the Substance hierarchy to define the structural modification of another concept

formalpara.title: Utility
formalpara.para: The Is modification attribute allows for the definition of Substances that are modifications of other Substances.

formalpara.title: Example
formalpara.para: Rilmenidine phosphate (substance) has an Is modification of Rilmenidine (substance)

table.title: Specimen Relationship Types Sub-Domain and Range

row.entry: Anatomical or acquired body structure (body structure)

formalpara.title: Definition
formalpara.para: Specimen source morphology is used in the Specimen hierarchy to specify the morphologic abnormality from which the specimen was obtained.

formalpara.title: Utility
formalpara.para: Specimen source morphology is useful for defining the morphologic change the Specimen concept was obtained from.

formalpara.title: Example
formalpara.para: Swab from abscess of brain (specimen) has a Specimen source morphology of Abscess (morphologic abnormality).

formalpara.title: Definition
formalpara.para: Specimen source topography is used in the Specimen hierarchy to specify the anatomical or acquired body structure from which the specimen was obtained.

formalpara.title: Utility
formalpara.para: Specimen source morphology is useful for defining the body structure the Specimen concept was obtained from.

formalpara.title: Example
formalpara.para: Excised breast ectopic tissue sample (specimen) has a Specimen source topography of Breast structure (body structure).

formalpara.title: Definition
formalpara.para: Specimen source identity is used in the Specimen hierarchy to specify the person, group or location from which a specimen was collected.

formalpara.title: Utility
formalpara.para: Specimen source identity is useful for defining the entity from which a Specimen concepts was obtained.

formalpara.title: Example
formalpara.para: Environmental swab (specimen) has a Specimen source identity of Environment (environment).

formalpara.title: Definition
formalpara.para: Specimen procedure is used in the Specimen hierarchy to represent the procedure perfomed to obtain the specimen.

formalpara.title: Utility
formalpara.para: Specimen procedure is useful for defining Specimen concepts that are obtained by performing a procedure.

formalpara.title: Example
formalpara.para: Specimen from eye obtained by fine needle aspiration biopsy (specimen) has a Specimen procedure of Fine needle aspiration biopsy of eye (procedure).

formalpara.title: Definition
formalpara.para: Specimen substance is used in the Specimen hierarchy to specify the type of substance a specimen is comprised.

formalpara.title: Utility
formalpara.para: Specimen substance is useful for defining the substance the Specimen concept is comprised of.

formalpara.title: Example
formalpara.para: Arterial blood specimen (specimen) has a Specimen substance of Arterial blood (substance).
